raw_text:
What really divides the parties
 
 So what is the gap between Labour and the Tories nowadays?
 
 One Starbucks, one Rymans and one small Greek cafe as it happens. Both parties have now completed their moves to new headquarters, with Labour creating its election hub just three doors away from the Tories' new headquarters in Victoria Street, just down the road from the Commons. That should make things a little easier if and when the crack-of-dawn election press conferences kick off. Unlike 2001, there should be no need for colleagues to have taxis gunning their engines outside, or to buy scooters, to get themselves between the tightly-timetabled events.
 
 And, to all intents and purposes, we already appear to be in that general election campaign. Certainly the press conference hosted by election co-ordinator Alan Milburn, in the rather compact new conference room - still smelling of new carpet and with the garish New Labour coffee mugs as yet unstained - had all the hallmarks of an election event.
 
 "Welcome to the unremittingly New Labour media centre," he said. And I'll bet he hadn't checked that one with Gordon Brown. Along with Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson and Minister for Work Jane Kennedy, he then went on to tear into the Tory plans to scrap the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme, which they claimed would lead to an increase of almost 300,000 in unemployment. And they ridiculed the claims made on Monday by Michael Howard that he could save £35 billion of Labour waste and inefficiency to spend on public services while also offering £4 billion of tax cuts. Labour has come up with a figure of £22 billions worth of efficiency savings so, understandably perhaps, believe Mr Howard must be planning cuts to squeeze the extra £13 billion. These figures, based on the two parties' own detailed studies, will be battered to within an inch of their lives during the campaign. Wednesday was just the start.
llama3.2:1b: The gap between Labour and the Tories is growing as they complete their new headquarters locations.
The press conference hosted by election co-ordinator Alan Milburn had all the hallmarks of an election event, with Labour leaders tearing into Tory plans.
Labour has responded with figures showing a potential £22 billion in efficiency savings to be cut, which will be "battered" during the campaign.
llama3.2:3b: Labour and Tories have both moved to new headquarters near Victoria Street in London, with Labour's election hub nearby.
A press conference hosted by Alan Milburn marked the beginning of the general election campaign, with Labour criticizing Tory plans for welfare-to-work schemes and tax cuts.
The parties will engage in a detailed battle over figures on efficiency savings and waste reduction during the campaign.
gemma2:2b: Both Labour and the Tories have moved into new headquarters close to each other, signaling the beginning of the general election campaign.
The Labour party held a press conference that showcased its contrasting policies and criticisms of the Tory plans on welfare-to-work schemes and public service spending.
The two parties are using detailed studies to attack each other's figures, with Labour emphasizing its efficiency savings and criticizing the Tories for proposing cuts to achieve similar outcomes.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In recent years, there has been a significant gap between Labour and the Tories in terms of their office space and infrastructure.
Labour has moved its headquarters three doors away from the Tories' location in Victoria Street and created its election hub nearby.
However, this seems to have left them without the same level of central planning and coordination.
The media center Alan Milburn hosted during the press conferences has also been described as an "election event."
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Labour and Tory headquarters have merged in preparation for the 2024 general election.
The media centre has been upgraded with New Labour coffee mugs, indicating a shift towards the campaign's rhetoric.
qwen2.5:3b: What really divides the Labour and Tory parties nowadays appears minimalistic with both forming new headquarters near each other in Victoria Street, reducing travel time for press conferences.

The election atmosphere is already present; a conference hosted by Alan Milburn featured Labour criticizing Tory plans to scrap welfare-to-work schemes and ridiculing their claims of £35 billion savings.
Labour counters with its own studies showing £22 billion efficiency savings, leading them to suspect the Tories will implement cuts to manage any extra £13 billion.
opencoder:1.5b: What really divides the parties is that both Labour and the Tories have already completed their moves to new headquarters with Labour creating its election hub three doors away from the Tories' new headquarters in Victoria Street, down the road from the Commons.

1.
The main difference between Labour and the Tories is that Labour has created its election hub in a new location, while the Tories have moved to a new headquarters in Victoria Street.
Both parties have now completed their moves to new headquarters.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The text discusses the division between Labour and Tories, highlighting their recent moves.
It notes that both parties now have new headquarters near Victoria Street, with Labour's head closer to the Tories' office.
The press conference hosted by Alan Milburn in a compact room is described as an election event, critiquing Tory welfare-to-work plans and criticizing figures on job saving claims.
Key figures like Gordon Brown and Mr. Howard are mentioned with associated financial figures from their parties.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite a new headquarter location for Labour, the Tories have yet to move into their election hubs in Victoria Street and Rymans.
There is also no need for taxis or scooters between events, as both parties have set up their own media centers in the same building.

The press conference was hosted by Alan Milburn, who mentioned plans to increase unemployment due to scrapping the New Deal scheme and claiming cuts of £35 billion of Labour waste and inefficiency will save £22 billion for tax cuts.

The parties' figures on efficiency savings have been debunked by Labour, but the press conference was a reminder that elections are not just about winning at the polls, but also about managing media coverage and creating memorable moments during election events.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The gap between Labour and the Tories has narrowed considerably as they continue to move their election hubs into new premises closer to each other.
This makes it easier for them to coordinate their events, as they can avoid having taxis and scooters waiting outside for them or spending time buying new equipment like press conferences.
It also means that the parties' staff and campaigners don't have to travel long distances to attend meetings or interviews, resulting in quicker decision-making and planning.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses the gap between Labour and the Tories in terms of their new headquarters.
Both parties have recently moved their headquarters, making it easier for them to hold press conferences and other events without needing taxis or scooters.

However, there is still a sense that they are already in an election campaign due to Milburn's event being described as unremittingly New Labour with a focus on attacking the Tories' plans to scrap the New Deal.
orca-mini:3b: What really divides Labour and the Tories is their differences in political ideology, policies, and strategies for government.
hermes3:3b: Labour and Conservative move to new headquarters nearby; election campaign features starting.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour and the Tories have moved into new headquarters nearby each other, making it easier for colleagues to navigate between election hubs and press conferences.
The appearance of a general election campaign is evident, with Labour criticizing Tory plans to scrap the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme and questioning Michael Howard's £35 billion claim.
Labour has proposed £22 billion in efficiency savings, leading the Tories to question whether they are planning cuts.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Labour and the Conservatives have moved their headquarters close to each other in Victoria Street, signaling the unofficial start of the general election campaign.

At a press conference, Labour's Alan Milburn, alongside Alan Johnson and Jane Kennedy, criticized Tory plans to scrap the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme, arguing it would increase unemployment by 300,000.
They also challenged Michael Howard’s claim that £35 billion in Labour inefficiencies could be redirected to public services while cutting taxes, suggesting his plans would require additional cuts.
These financial claims are expected to be heavily debated throughout the campaign.
stablelm2:1.6b: The text discusses how Labour and the Tories have both moved to new headquarters for their respective political parties.

The Labour party's election hub is located just three doors away from the Tories' new headquarters in Victoria Street, making it easier for staff to move between events during an upcoming election campaign.
This early sign of the election suggests that the press conference hosted by Alan Milburn at the New Labour media centre may be indicative of the upcoming battle between the two parties.
Labour has disputed the Tory plans to scrap the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme and criticized Michael Howard's claims regarding tax cuts and efficiency savings.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In a symbolic move, Labour and the Conservatives have each moved into nearby headquarters in Victoria Street, London.
This proximity suggests an early start to the 2015 general election campaign.

During an event at Labour's new media center, led by co-ordinator Alan Milburn, Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson, and Minister for Work Jane Kennedy, the opposition party criticized the Conservatives' plans to scrap the New Deal welfare-to-work program, predicting a 300,000 increase in unemployment.
Labour also challenged Michael Howard's claim of £35 billion in waste reduction and £4 billion for tax cuts, proposing their own figure of £22 billion in efficiency savings.
These figures are expected to be extensively debated during the campaign.
